juzSummary: Juz 7 bridges the end of Al-Ma'idah and the beginning of Al-An'am, transitioning from the last Madani legislation to the powerful Makkan call to monotheism. Al-Ma'idah closes with profound stories — the disciples asking Isa (AS) for a heavenly table, Isa denying he ever told people to worship him or his mother, and critical rulings on intoxicants, oaths, and hunting during pilgrimage. Then Al-An'am opens with a thundering declaration of Allah's sovereignty over creation, Ibrahim's rational journey to find God, and a roster of eighteen prophets whose way we are told to follow. The overarching message is clear: worship Allah alone, follow His messengers sincerely, and do not let worldly distractions or false gods divert you from the truth.

surahBreakdowns.name: Al-Ma'idah
surahBreakdowns.meaningOfName: Named after the 'table spread with food' that the disciples of Isa (AS) requested from heaven (5:112-115), symbolizing Allah's ability to provide miracles and the gravity of asking for signs then disbelieving.
surahBreakdowns.revelationContext: Revealed in Madinah. This is considered one of the last Surahs revealed, addressing final rulings on halal and haram, interfaith relations, and establishing the completeness of the Deen. These closing verses settle matters of covenants, accountability, and Isa's true message.
surahBreakdowns.coreTheme: The completion of divine legislation, the accountability of nations before Allah, and the absolute clarity that Isa (AS) was a servant and messenger of Allah — not divine.
keyTeachings: Christians are described as closest in affection to the believers due to their priests and monks and because they are not arrogant (5:82). Recognize goodness where it exists, even across religious boundaries.
Intoxicants and gambling are declared tools of Shaytan designed to create enmity and distract from the remembrance of Allah (5:90-91). This is one of the clearest prohibitions in the Quran.
Allah tells us 'Upon you is responsibility for yourselves. Those who have gone astray will not harm you when you have been guided' (5:105) — focus on your own obedience before worrying about others.
The story of the table spread (5:112-115) shows that miracles do not guarantee faith. The disciples asked for a sign, received it, and were warned of severe punishment if they disbelieved after it.

On the Day of Judgment, Allah will ask Isa directly: 'Did you tell people to take you and your mother as gods?' and Isa will deny it completely (5:116-117), clarifying his true message was pure Tawheed.

standoutAyah.arabic: مَا قُلْتُ لَهُمْ إِلَّا مَا أَمَرْتَنِي بِهِ أَنِ اعْبُدُوا اللَّهَ رَبِّي وَرَبَّكُمْ
standoutAyah.transliteration: Ma qultu lahum illa ma amartani bihi ani'budu Allaha Rabbi wa Rabbakum
standoutAyah.translation: I said not to them except what You commanded me — to worship Allah, my Lord and your Lord.
standoutAyah.reflection: Isa (AS) stands before Allah on the Day of Judgment and his defense is beautifully simple: I only told them what You told me. This is the ultimate model of a messenger — no ego, no additions, no distortions. It also invites us to ask: am I following what the messengers actually taught, or what people later attributed to them?

surahBreakdowns.name: Al-An'am
surahBreakdowns.meaningOfName: Named after the cattle and livestock that the polytheists falsely dedicated to their idols and imposed superstitious rules upon (discussed later in the Surah), highlighting how people invent religious laws without divine authority.
surahBreakdowns.revelationContext: Revealed in Makkah, reportedly in a single revelation. It came during a period of intense opposition to the Prophet (ﷺ) and addresses the core arguments of the Quraysh against monotheism, resurrection, and prophethood. It is purely theological, with no legislation.
surahBreakdowns.coreTheme: An uncompromising declaration of Tawheed — Allah alone is the Creator, Sustainer, and only One worthy of worship. The Surah systematically dismantles every argument for polytheism using logic, nature, and prophetic history.
keyTeachings: Allah opens by declaring He created the heavens and earth, made darkness and light, yet people still set up equals to Him (6:1). Gratitude to the Creator should logically lead to worshipping Him alone.
Not a leaf falls without His knowledge, and there is no grain in the darkness of the earth nor anything moist or dry except that it is recorded (6:59). Allah's knowledge is total and intimate.

Ibrahim's journey through observing the star, the moon, and the sun (6:76-79) is a masterclass in using reason to arrive at faith. He rejected each one as it set, concluding that the true God does not disappear.

Eighteen prophets are listed together (6:83-86) — including Ibrahim, Ishaq, Yaqub, Nuh, Dawud, Sulayman, Ayyub, Yusuf, Musa, Harun, Zakariyya, Yahya, Isa, Ilyas, Isma'il, Al-Yasa', Yunus, and Lut — showing that monotheism was the consistent message throughout history.
Do not insult those whom others worship besides Allah, lest they insult Allah in retaliation out of ignorance (6:108). Even in defending the truth, maintain wisdom and avoid provoking harm.

standoutAyah.arabic: وَعِندَهُ مَفَاتِحُ الْغَيْبِ لَا يَعْلَمُهَا إِلَّا هُوَ وَيَعْلَمُ مَا فِي الْبَرِّ وَالْبَحْرِ وَمَا تَسْقُطُ مِن وَرَقَةٍ إِلَّا يَعْلَمُهَا
standoutAyah.transliteration: Wa 'indahu mafatihu al-ghaybi la ya'lamuha illa Huwa wa ya'lamu ma fi al-barri wal-bahri wa ma tasqutu min waraqatin illa ya'lamuha
standoutAyah.translation: And with Him are the keys of the unseen; none knows them except Him. And He knows what is on the land and in the sea. Not a leaf falls but that He knows it.
standoutAyah.reflection: This verse should both humble and comfort you. You don't know what tomorrow holds — but Allah does, down to every single leaf that falls. Your worries, your prayers, your silent struggles — nothing escapes His knowledge. If He tracks every leaf, He is certainly tracking your life.

connectingTheDots: Al-Ma'idah ends by settling the question of Isa (AS) once and for all: he was a servant of Allah, not divine, and he will testify to this on the Day of Judgment. Al-An'am then picks up this theme of Tawheed with full force, opening with the declaration that Allah alone created the heavens and earth and proceeding to dismantle every form of polytheism through rational arguments, the story of Ibrahim, and the united testimony of eighteen prophets. Both Surahs, from different angles, drive home the same truth: worship belongs to Allah alone.

coreThemes.name: Pure Monotheism (Tawheed)
coreThemes.explanation: Both portions of this Juz converge on the absolute oneness of Allah. Al-Ma'idah closes by having Isa (AS) himself reject any divinity attributed to him, while Al-An'am systematically argues for Tawheed through creation, logic, nature, and prophetic history. Ibrahim's famous rejection of celestial bodies as gods (6:76-79) demonstrates that reason itself leads to monotheism.
coreThemes.dailyRelevance: In Ramadan, examine your own subtle forms of 'shirk' — not idol worship, but placing excessive dependence on wealth, status, people, or your own abilities instead of Allah. Today, consciously redirect your trust and reliance back to Allah alone in at least one area of your life.

coreThemes.name: Accountability and Divine Knowledge
coreThemes.explanation: From the oaths and rulings in Al-Ma'idah to the 'not a leaf falls' verse in Al-An'am, this Juz emphasizes that nothing escapes Allah's awareness. Every word we speak, every commitment we make, and every secret we harbor is known to Him. The Day of Judgment scenes — where even prophets will be questioned — underscore that accountability is universal.
coreThemes.dailyRelevance: Fasting trains us in exactly this awareness: no one sees you when you're alone, yet you refrain from food and drink because Allah sees. Carry that same consciousness into your speech, your screen time, and your private thoughts today.

coreThemes.name: Respecting Boundaries
coreThemes.explanation: Al-Ma'idah addresses specific boundaries: don't prohibit what Allah made lawful (5:87), don't consume intoxicants or gamble (5:90-91), observe hunting restrictions during ihram (5:94-96), and don't pry into matters that may distress you (5:101). Al-An'am adds: don't insult what others worship (6:108). Islam is precise about its limits, and wisdom lies in observing them.
coreThemes.dailyRelevance: During Ramadan, we're already practicing boundary-keeping by controlling what enters our bodies. Extend that to what exits your mouth — avoid harsh words, unnecessary debates, and insults, even toward those you disagree with.

keyAyat.arabic: لَتَجِدَنَّ أَشَدَّ النَّاسِ عَدَاوَةً لِّلَّذِينَ آمَنُوا الْيَهُودَ وَالَّذِينَ أَشْرَكُوا وَلَتَجِدَنَّ أَقْرَبَهُم مَّوَدَّةً لِّلَّذِينَ آمَنُوا الَّذِينَ قَالُوا إِنَّا نَصَارَىٰ
keyAyat.transliteration: Latajidanna ashadda an-nasi 'adawatan lilladhina amanu al-Yahuda walladhina ashraku wa latajidanna aqrabahum mawaddatan lilladhina amanu alladhina qalu inna Nasara
keyAyat.translation: You will surely find the most intense of the people in animosity toward the believers to be the Jews and those who associate others with Allah; and you will find the nearest of them in affection to the believers those who say, 'We are Christians.'
keyAyat.significance: This verse speaks to the historical context of the early Muslim community and acknowledges that sincere people of any background can have hearts open to truth. It recognizes humility and sincerity as qualities that bring people closer to faith.
keyAyat.reflectionPrompt: Do you judge people by their labels or by their character and sincerity? How can you look for genuine goodness in people regardless of their background?

keyAyat.arabic: يَا أَيُّهَا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا عَلَيْكُمْ أَنفُسَكُمْ لَا يَضُرُّكُم مَّن ضَلَّ إِذَا اهْتَدَيْتُمْ
keyAyat.transliteration: Ya ayyuha alladhina amanu 'alaykum anfusakum la yadurrukum man dalla idha ihtadaytum
keyAyat.translation: O you who have believed, upon you is [responsibility for] yourselves. Those who have gone astray will not harm you when you have been guided.
keyAyat.significance: A liberating verse that refocuses our energy. While enjoining good and forbidding evil remains important, this verse reminds us that our primary obligation is our own soul. Others' choices will not diminish our standing if we are on the right path.
keyAyat.reflectionPrompt: Are you spending more energy worrying about others' behavior than working on your own? What is one area of personal growth you've been neglecting while focusing outward?

keyAyat.arabic: وَإِن يَمْسَسْكَ اللَّهُ بِضُرٍّ فَلَا كَاشِفَ لَهُ إِلَّا هُوَ وَإِن يَمْسَسْكَ بِخَيْرٍ فَهُوَ عَلَىٰ كُلِّ شَيْءٍ قَدِيرّ
keyAyat.transliteration: Wa in yamsaska Allahu bidurrin fala kashifa lahu illa Huwa wa in yamsaska bikhayrin faHuwa 'ala kulli shay'in Qadir
keyAyat.translation: And if Allah should touch you with adversity, there is no remover of it except Him. And if He touches you with good, then He is over all things competent.
keyAyat.significance: This verse establishes that both hardship and ease come from Allah alone, and only He can relieve difficulty. It eliminates the need to seek relief from any other source and builds a direct, unmediated relationship with the Creator.
keyAyat.reflectionPrompt: When you face a difficulty, who or what do you turn to first? How can you train yourself to make du'a to Allah your instinctive first response rather than an afterthought?

keyAyat.arabic: لَّا تُدْرِكُهُ الْأَبْصَارُ وَهُوَ يُدْرِكُ الْأَبْصَارَ وَهُوَ اللَّطِيفُ الْخَبِيرُ
keyAyat.transliteration: La tudrikuhu al-absaru wa Huwa yudriku al-absara wa Huwa al-Latifu al-Khabir
keyAyat.translation: Vision perceives Him not, but He perceives all vision; and He is the Subtle, the Acquainted.
keyAyat.significance: One of the most powerful descriptions of Allah in the Quran. We cannot encompass Him with our senses, yet He is aware of every detail of our existence. The names Al-Latif (the Subtle) and Al-Khabir (the All-Aware) capture His nature: gentle in His knowledge, thorough in His awareness.
keyAyat.reflectionPrompt: How does knowing that Allah perceives everything — while remaining beyond your perception — change the way you think about His closeness to you?

keyAyat.arabic: وَلَا تَسُبُّوا الَّذِينَ يَدْعُونَ مِن دُونِ اللَّهِ فَيَسُبُّوا اللَّهَ عَدْوًا بِغَيْرِ عِلْمٍ
keyAyat.transliteration: Wa la tasubbu alladhina yad'una min duni Allahi fayasubbu Allaha 'adwan bighayri 'ilm
keyAyat.translation: And do not insult those they invoke other than Allah, lest they insult Allah in enmity without knowledge.
keyAyat.significance: A remarkable verse on the ethics of religious discourse. Even when defending the truth, we are commanded to avoid provocation that could lead to greater harm. Protecting Allah's name from insult takes precedence over winning an argument.
keyAyat.reflectionPrompt: Think about how you engage in discussions about religion or beliefs. Do your words invite people toward the truth, or do they provoke defensiveness and hostility?

hadithOfTheDay.text: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: 'Every intoxicant is khamr, and every intoxicant is haram (forbidden).'
hadithOfTheDay.reflection: Connecting directly to Al-Ma'idah 5:90-91, this hadith broadens the prohibition beyond just wine to every substance that intoxicates. In Ramadan, we're already abstaining from food and drink during the day — use this momentum to evaluate any habit that clouds your judgment or distances you from Allah, whether it's a substance, an addiction to screens, or anything that intoxicates your attention.

dailyPractice: Today, practice Ibrahim's method from 6:76-79. Before Maghrib, step outside and look at the sky — the sun setting, the first stars appearing. Instead of scrolling through your phone, spend five minutes observing creation and reflecting: this beauty didn't create itself, and it doesn't sustain itself. Let the natural world point you toward its Creator, just as it pointed Ibrahim. Then make your Maghrib prayer with that renewed sense of awe.

discussionQuestions.reflectionQuestion: In 5:116-117, Isa (AS) will stand before Allah and say he only taught what he was commanded. If you were asked by Allah what you taught the people in your circle of influence — your family, your friends, your colleagues — what would your answer be? Are you modeling the message you claim to believe in?
discussionQuestions.applicationQuestion: Al-An'am 6:108 tells us not to insult what others worship, even though we disagree. Think about a recent conversation where you discussed religion or values with someone who sees things differently. Did you speak in a way that opened a door or closed one? What is one specific way you can improve your approach this week?

habitCheckIn: Day 7 — you've completed a full week of this journey. By now, you should have a rhythm: reading, reflecting, praying. If you've missed a day or two, don't let that discourage you — pick up right here. Today, check in on one specific habit: are you making du'a at iftar time? The Prophet (ﷺ) told us the fasting person has a supplication that is not rejected. Don't waste this window. Have a list of three du'as ready before you break your fast tonight.
closingMessage: One full week in. You've journeyed from Al-Fatihah's prayer for guidance all the way through the legislative foundation of Al-Ma'idah and into the theological powerhouse of Al-An'am. Ibrahim looked at the stars and found Allah. The disciples asked for a table from heaven and received it. You're reading the same Book that guided them all. Keep going — the best is yet to come.
closingDua: رَبَّنَا آمَنَّا فَاكْتُبْنَا مَعَ الشَّاهِدِينَ — Our Lord, we have believed, so register us among the witnesses. (5:83)

stories.title: Isa and the Heavenly Table
stories.subtitle: When the disciples asked for a miracle from heaven
stories.triggerLabel: The Story of the Heavenly Table (Al-Ma'idah)
paragraphs: The disciples of Isa (AS) came to him one day with an extraordinary request. They said, 'O Isa, son of Maryam, can your Lord send down to us a table spread with food from heaven?' It was not that they doubted Allah's power — they wanted their hearts to be at rest, to witness a sign with their own eyes, and to be among those who could testify to it. Isa (AS) cautioned them first: 'Fear Allah, if you should be believers.' But they persisted.

Isa (AS) then raised his hands and called upon Allah: 'O Allah, our Lord, send down to us a table spread from heaven to be for us a festival for the first of us and the last of us and a sign from You. And provide for us, and You are the best of providers.' It was a prayer of humility and purpose — not asking for a spectacle, but for a sign that would mark a celebration for his community and strengthen their conviction.

Allah answered the prayer, but with a solemn warning: 'Indeed, I will send it down to you, but whoever disbelieves afterwards from among you — then indeed will I punish him with a punishment by which I have not punished anyone among the worlds.' The table descended from heaven, a miracle witnessed by the disciples. It was a moment of overwhelming awe and gratitude.

The story carries a profound lesson that echoes across time. Miracles do not guarantee faith. The very people who received this sign were warned that disbelief after witnessing it would bring the harshest of consequences. In our own lives, we often ask Allah for signs — show me and I'll believe, give me this and I'll be grateful. But the question is never whether Allah can provide. The question is whether we will remain faithful after He does.

relevantVerses.arabic: إِذْ قَالَ الْحَوَارِيُّونَ يَا عِيسَى ابْنَ مَرْيَمَ هَلْ يَسْتَطِيعُ رَبُّكَ أَن يُنَزِّلَ عَلَيْنَا مَائِدَةً مِّنَ السَّمَاءِ
relevantVerses.transliteration: Idh qala al-hawariyyuna ya 'Isa ibna Maryama hal yastati'u Rabbuka an yunazzila 'alayna ma'idatan mina as-sama'i
relevantVerses.translation: When the disciples said, 'O Isa, son of Maryam, can your Lord send down to us a table spread from the sky?'

relevantVerses.arabic: قَالَ اللَّهُ إِنِّي مُنَزِّلُهَا عَلَيْكُمْ فَمَن يَكْفُرْ بَعْدُ مِنكُمْ فَإِنِّي أُعَذِّبُهُ عَذَابًا لَّا أُعَذِّبُهُ أَحَدًا مِّنَ الْعَالَمِينَ
relevantVerses.transliteration: Qala Allahu inni munazziluha 'alaykum faman yakfur ba'du minkum fa'inni u'adhdhibuhu 'adhaban la u'adhdhibuhu ahadan mina al-'alamin
relevantVerses.translation: Allah said, 'Indeed, I will send it down to you, but whoever disbelieves afterwards from among you — then indeed will I punish him with a punishment by which I have not punished anyone among the worlds.'

lessonsLearned: Miracles strengthen faith only for those whose hearts are already inclined toward truth. Seeking signs without inner readiness leads to greater accountability, not greater conviction.
When Allah answers your prayers and provides for you, the response must be lasting gratitude — not temporary excitement followed by forgetfulness.
True faith does not require seeing to believe. The strongest believers are those who trust in the unseen, as described at the very beginning of Al-Baqarah (2:3).

stories.title: Ibrahim's Journey to Find God
stories.subtitle: Using reason to arrive at the truth
stories.triggerLabel: The Story of Ibrahim (AS) and the Stars
paragraphs: Ibrahim (AS) grew up in a society steeped in idol worship. His father Azar was himself a maker of idols. But Ibrahim carried within him a restless intellect and a heart that could not settle for inherited falsehood. Allah describes his journey to truth not as blind acceptance, but as a rational search — and it begins with him looking at the sky.

When night fell and Ibrahim saw a star, he said, 'This is my lord.' But when the star set and disappeared below the horizon, he said, 'I do not like those that set.' He was testing each celestial body against the criteria of what a true god must be: permanent, self-sufficient, and unchanging. When the moon rose in all its brilliance, he said, 'This is my lord.' But it too set, and Ibrahim declared, 'Unless my Lord guides me, I will surely be among the people gone astray.'

Then the sun rose — the most magnificent object in the sky, the source of light and life. Ibrahim said, 'This is my lord; this is greater.' But when even the mighty sun set, Ibrahim reached his conclusion with absolute clarity: 'O my people, indeed I am free from what you associate with Allah. Indeed, I have turned my face toward He who created the heavens and the earth, inclining toward truth, and I am not of those who associate others with Allah.'

What makes Ibrahim's story extraordinary is that Allah presents it as a model of how reason leads to faith. Ibrahim did not need a book or a prophet to arrive at monotheism — he observed the natural world and followed the logic to its conclusion. Anything that sets, changes, or depends on something else cannot be God. Only the One who created it all — who is beyond setting, beyond change, beyond need — deserves worship. This is the fitrah (natural disposition) that every human being carries.

relevantVerses.arabic: فَلَمَّا جَنَّ عَلَيْهِ اللَّيْلُ رَأَىٰ كَوْكَبًا قَالَ هَٰذَا رَبِّي فَلَمَّا أَفَلَ قَالَ لَا أُحِبُّ الْآفِلِينَ
relevantVerses.transliteration: Falamma janna 'alayhi al-laylu ra'a kawkaban qala hadha Rabbi falamma afala qala la uhibbu al-afilin
relevantVerses.translation: So when the night covered him [with darkness], he saw a star. He said, 'This is my lord.' But when it set, he said, 'I like not those that set.'

relevantVerses.arabic: إِنِّي وَجَّهْتُ وَجْهِيَ لِلَّذِي فَطَرَ السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضَ حَنِيفًا وَمَا أَنَا مِنَ الْمُشْرِكِينَ
relevantVerses.transliteration: Inni wajjahtu wajhiya lilladhi fatara as-samawati wal-arda hanifan wa ma ana mina al-mushrikin
relevantVerses.translation: Indeed, I have turned my face toward He who created the heavens and the earth, inclining toward truth, and I am not of those who associate others with Allah.

lessonsLearned: Faith and reason are not enemies — Ibrahim used logic and observation to arrive at monotheism, and Allah presents his method approvingly as a model for all people.

Anything in your life that 'sets' — wealth that can vanish, health that can decline, people who can leave — cannot be your ultimate source of security. Only Allah, who never changes and never diminishes, deserves that place in your heart.
It takes courage to reject the beliefs of your family and society when they contradict the truth. Ibrahim stood alone against his entire community, and Allah honored him for it.

stories.title: Isa's Testimony Before Allah
stories.subtitle: The Day of Judgment scene where Isa (AS) clears his name
stories.triggerLabel: The Story of Isa (AS) on the Day of Judgment
paragraphs: The Quran presents a scene from the Day of Judgment that is both dramatic and deeply moving. Allah will gather all of creation, and among those questioned will be Isa ibn Maryam (AS) — Jesus, the son of Mary. Allah will ask him directly: 'O Isa, son of Maryam, did you say to the people, "Take me and my mother as deities besides Allah?"'

Isa's response is a masterclass in humility and servitude. He will say, 'Exalted are You! It was not for me to say that to which I have no right. If I had said it, You would have known it. You know what is within myself, and I do not know what is within Yourself. Indeed, it is You who is Knower of the unseen.' He does not defend himself with arguments or excuses. He simply affirms Allah's complete knowledge and his own complete submission.

He continues: 'I said not to them except what You commanded me — to worship Allah, my Lord and your Lord. And I was a witness over them as long as I was among them; but when You took me up, You were the Observer over them, and You are, over all things, Witness.' Isa (AS) makes clear that his mission was singular: calling people to worship Allah alone. Whatever happened after he was raised was beyond his control and not his responsibility.

This scene serves multiple purposes. It definitively settles the theological question of Isa's nature — he was a servant and messenger, not divine. It also provides a model for every believer: when you stand before Allah, your defense should be the same. Did you convey what you were commanded? Did you worship Allah alone? Did you remain faithful to the message? That is all that will matter.

relevantVerses.arabic: وَإِذْ قَالَ اللَّهُ يَا عِيسَى ابْنَ مَرْيَمَ أَأَنتَ قُلتَ لِلنَّاسِ اتَّخِذُونِي وَأُمِّيَ إِلَٰهَيْنِ مِن دُونِ اللَّهِ
relevantVerses.transliteration: Wa idh qala Allahu ya 'Isa ibna Maryama a'anta qulta linnasi ittakhidhuni wa ummiya ilahayni min duni Allahi
relevantVerses.translation: And [beware the Day] when Allah will say, 'O Isa, son of Maryam, did you say to the people, "Take me and my mother as deities besides Allah?"'

relevantVerses.arabic: مَا قُلْتُ لَهُمْ إِلَّا مَا أَمَرْتَنِي بِهِ أَنِ اعْبُدُوا اللَّهَ رَبِّي وَرَبَّكُمْ
relevantVerses.transliteration: Ma qultu lahum illa ma amartani bihi ani'budu Allaha Rabbi wa Rabbakum
relevantVerses.translation: I said not to them except what You commanded me — to worship Allah, my Lord and your Lord.

lessonsLearned: Even the greatest of prophets will be questioned on the Day of Judgment. No one is exempt from accountability before Allah, and this should motivate us to examine our own words and actions.
The true message of every prophet, including Isa (AS), was Tawheed — the worship of Allah alone. Any teaching that contradicts this core message is a later human addition, not divine revelation.
When you stand before Allah, the best defense is the simplest: 'I only said and did what You commanded.' Strive to make your life align with that statement.

dailyDuas.translation: Our Lord, we have believed, so register us among the witnesses.
dailyDuas.context: This is the response of the sincere Christians who, upon hearing the Quran recited, recognized its truth and wept. Their eyes overflowed with tears and they said this prayer, asking Allah to count them among those who bear witness to the truth. It captures the moment of genuine recognition and surrender.

dailyDuas.arabic: اللَّهُمَّ رَبَّنَا أَنزِلْ عَلَيْنَا مَائِدَةً مِّنَ السَّمَاءِ تَكُونُ لَنَا عِيدًا لِّأَوَّلِنَا وَآخِرِنَا وَآيَةً مِّنكَ وَارْزُقْنَا وَأَنتَ خَيْرُ الرَّازِقِينَ
dailyDuas.transliteration: Allahumma Rabbana anzil 'alayna ma'idatan mina as-sama'i takunu lana 'idan li'awwalina wa akhirina wa ayatan minka warzuqna wa Anta khayru ar-raziqin
dailyDuas.translation: O Allah, our Lord, send down to us a table spread from the sky to be for us a festival for the first of us and the last of us and a sign from You. And provide for us, and You are the best of providers.
dailyDuas.context: This is the du'a of Isa (AS) himself, made on behalf of his disciples who asked for a heavenly table. It is a model prayer: it asks for provision, acknowledges it as a sign from Allah, frames it as a blessing for the entire community, and closes by affirming that Allah is the ultimate Provider.

dailyDuas.arabic: إِنِّي وَجَّهْتُ وَجْهِيَ لِلَّذِي فَطَرَ السَّمَاوَاتِ وَالْأَرْضَ حَنِيفًا وَمَا أَنَا مِنَ الْمُشْرِكِينَ
dailyDuas.transliteration: Inni wajjahtu wajhiya lilladhi fatara as-samawati wal-arda hanifan wa ma ana mina al-mushrikin
dailyDuas.translation: Indeed, I have turned my face toward He who created the heavens and the earth, inclining toward truth, and I am not of those who associate others with Allah.
dailyDuas.context: This is the declaration of Ibrahim (AS) after his famous rational journey through observing the star, the moon, and the sun. After each celestial body set and disappeared, Ibrahim concluded that the true God is the One who created them all. This statement became a foundational expression of monotheism, and the Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) himself would recite similar words when beginning his prayer.
